A dental abscess is a build-up of pus in the teeth or gums caused by an infection. It needs urgent treatment by a dentist. A dental abscess will not go away on its own.

sections.title: Urgent advice:Ask for an urgent dentist appointment or get help from NHS 111 if:
paragraphs: Do not go to a GP surgery as they will not be able to give you dental treatment.

sections.title: If you do not have a dentist or cannot get to an emergency appointment:
paragraphs: You may have to pay for your appointment. Find out more aboutNHS dental charges.

sections.title: Immediate action required:Call 999 or go to A&E if:
paragraphs: Do not drive to A&E. Ask someone to drive you or call 999 and ask for an ambulance.
Bring any medicines you take with you.

sections.title: How to ease the pain caused by a dental abscess
paragraphs: There are some things you can do to help with the pain until you can get dental treatment.

sections.title: Do
paragraphs: take painkillers, such asibuprofenorparacetamol(children under 16 should not take aspirin)
eat soft foods like soup, scrambled eggs, mashed potatoes and yoghurt
use a soft toothbrush to clean your teeth
avoid having sugary, or very hot or cold, foods and drinks

sections.title: Treatment for a dental abscess
paragraphs: Dental abscesses are usually treated by a dentist. The dentist will drain away the pus.
If a problem with your tooth has caused the abscess, you may needroot canal treatment, or the tooth may be removed. You'll be given a local anaesthetic, so you do not feel any pain.
You may be offered painkillers to take for a few days after treatment and may also be given antibiotics.

sections.title: Causes of a dental abscess
paragraphs: Dental abscesses usually happen when pus builds up beneath your teeth or gums when you have an infection in your mouth.

sections.title: How to prevent dental abscesses
paragraphs: There are some things you can do to help prevent dental abscesses.

sections.title: Do
paragraphs: brush your teeth with fluoride toothpaste at least twice a day - spit after brushing, do not rinse
clean in between your teeth every day using floss or interdental brushes
replace your toothbrush every 1 to 3 months
have regulardental check-upsso problems can be spotted early

sections.title: Don’t
paragraphs: do not use mouthwash straight after brushing your teeth
do not smoke
